title: When will available Adult Intensive Care Unit (ICU) bed capacity in Arizona fall below 5.0%?
preds:
The highest value you can calculate from the official data seems to be: 07 July 2020:
Adult Intensive Care Unit Beds Available: 145 (amazing, how small they made this bar in the chart, and how hard it is to get to the figure by hovering...)
Adult Intensive Care Unit Beds in Use: 1,537
Total number (Adult Intensive Care Unit Beds) on 07 July 2020: 1,682
91.38% of capacity in use
8.62% of capacity available on 07 July 2020 After this date 07 July 2020, there were:
/9 consecutive days with 3,250 or more inpatients COVID-19, actually 9 out of 10 of the highest values on record.
/9 more days before the number of ventilators in use peaked on 16 July 2020 at 687 (up from 570)
/on 26 July 2020 the number of ventilators in use has been at 567, a number below the 07 July 2020 value, for the first time again
/number of ICU beds for COVID-19 was 870 on 07 July 2020; in the two following weeks  until 21 July 2020 this number was higher by approx. 45 beds on average (almost every day, except for 08 + 20 July 2020) with a peak 6 days after at 100 additional beds (13 July 2020 at 970 beds)
/in the six days between 07 July 2020 and 12 July 2020, there were 435 fatalities related to COVID-19, according to the "Deaths by Date of Death" chart. In the same time frame, there were 636 "Intubations COVID". Even under consideration of an increased discharge for four days (07 July:543; 08 July:538; 09 July:512; 10 July: 541. Compare to 05 July: 475; 06 July: 424) this does not really explain how they managed to have 35 ICU beds per day (!) at hand for an "excess in intubations over fatalities" without seeing the number of total ICU beds increase. It's magic. (Discharges are patients with milder symptoms in approx. 80% of the cases, patients from the Inpatient-, ED-cohort).
/The solution must lie in the rebranding of beds in the Emergency Department, without adding them to the count of total ICU beds, even though these beds had the same functionalities. The single highest jump in the number of "Patients seen in the Emergency Department (ED)" in the "COVID-19-ED" tab under "Hospital COVID-19 Specific Metrics" happened:
on 07 July 2020 (2,008), up from 1,385 on 06 July 2020.
This number remained higher than the 06 July value every single day until 18 July 2020, while an estimated staggering number of 3,850 additional patients have been seen in the ED. Considering the fact that on 07 July 2020 there were just 145 ICU beds available and it at that specific day only took 61 additional ICU patients to hit the threshold of 95% capacity, one must conclude that hospitals in Arizona - by general standards - ran at 100% or higher of capacity on every single day between 07 July 2020 and 18 July 2020. The only exceptions here will be a few hospitals in the counties Graham, Greenlee and La Paz.
/This is what is called "Crisis standards of care", which was enacted in Arizona in the beginning of July 2020 and will have been effective on 07 July 2020. The topic of data reliability is raised here: https://www.propublica.org/article/how-many-people-in-the-us-are-hospitalized-with-covid-19-who-knows Instead of providing better information to the public, the move on by the so called "Coronavirus Task Force" of 10 July 2020 only made things worse. The data collected from the HHS reveals, for instance, that coverage of reporting  of hispital beds in use is low, according to healthdata.gov, the data outlet of the HHS  https://healthdata.gov/dataset/covid-19-reported-patient-impact-and-hospital-capacity-state/resource/38e07d07-40a2-4749#{query:{filters:[{type:!term,field:!state,term:!az}]},view-grid:{hiddenColumns:[!inpatient_beds,!inpatient_beds_coverage,!inpatient_beds_used,!inpatient_beds_used_coverage,!inpatient_beds_utilization,!inpatient_beds_utilization_coverage,!inpatient_beds_utilization_numerator,!inpatient_beds_utilization_denominator],columnsWidth:[{column:!state,width:159},{column:!inpatient_beds,width:179},{column:!inpatient_beds_coverage,width:275},{column:!inpatient_beds_used,width:208},{column:!adult_icu_bed_covid_utilization_numerator,width:474},{column:!adult_icu_bed_covid_utilization_denominator,width:482},{column:!adult_icu_bed_utilization,width:260},{column:!adult_icu_bed_utilization_coverage,width:385},{column:!adult_icu_bed_utilization_numerator,width:423},{column:!adult_icu_bed_utilization_denominator,width:413},{column:!reporting_cutoff_start,width:195},{column:!entry_id,width:102}]}} "Inpatient beds used COVID Coverage": 86%
"Staffed Adult ICU Bed Occupancy Coverage":62%
"Percent of Inpatients with COVID Coverage": 69% [Percent of Inpatients with COVID Coverage numerator: 1932) "Adult ICU bed COVID Utilization Coverage": 50%
"Adult ICU bed COVID Utilization Coverage Numerator": 452
"Adult ICU bed COVID Utilization Coverage Denominator": 1049
"Adult ICU bed Utilization": 0.83984747...
"Adult ICU bed Utilization Coverage": 52%
"Adult ICU bed Utilization Numerator": 881
"Adult ICU bed Utilization Denominator": 1049
"Reporting Cutoff": 2020-07-27 Why is there a reporting cutoff on 27 July 2020? What happened to the data after that day? What is especially revealing: the HHS statistics cover only 1,049 or 52% of all Adult ICU beds. This means in total there must be at least 2,017 of them.
On 27 July 2020 ADHS reported 1,433 adult ICU beds in use, 272 adult ICU beds available (which totals 1,705, at a ratio of 84.05% for utilization.
The Healthdata.gov data now suggest there are 2017 or more adult ICU beds in Arizona, 312 more than state health official reported on, "covered"... Even though their coverage rate is at 84.53% (1,705 out of 2017 beds covered), it's not a full coverage of 100%. It's just a bit less bad than the data provided by the HHS. Strangely, the two different coverage ratios
50% for "Adult ICU bed COVID Utilization Coverage" and
52% for "Adult ICU bed Utilization Coverage",
by using the same denominator of 1,049, as they do, this implies an even higher total of Adult ICU beds in Arizona of 2,098 an a secret reserve of 81 beds they have, build as needed, or just make up in order to prevent the statistics from being as bad. If this is true, no wonder the "Adult Intensive Care Unit Beds Available"-ratio could never fall below the 8.62% as of 07 July 2020, if there exist beds that go uncovered, and there exist 81 phantom beds.
85% as of August 1st. Less than 5 % is not going to happen for a long time.

"The National Weather Service has issued an Excessive Heat Warning for 12 Arizona Counties. Coconino, Gila, Graham, Greenlee, La Paz, Mohave, Pima, Pinal, Santa Cruz, and Yavapai until 8/1 at 8 PM. The Heat Warning has been extended for Maricopa and Yuma until 8/3 8 PM. Daytime highs up to 119° F are expected." The only reason I haven't switched to the last bin completely... expect the unexpected.
Right now it is very high: 86%
Right now it is very high: 86%
15% still available as of 7/28, and it appears the numbers have been improving very gradually since the end of the first week of July.
I am tardy to the update party.
With my luck even this one will get complicated in the next 9 days...
situation in Arizona has improved to the point where this outcome is unlikely
It's upwards of 50% and has been for months.

The ICU beds usage numbers is the lowest they have been since 22 June. Other relevant stats like Hospital COVID-19 Specific Metrics and Laboratory testing is trending downwards. Was going to wait until the numbers for the 28th, but the numbers has convinced me that even if there is a jump upwards tomorrow the trend is clear. 24 Jul-6 Aug: -1
Not before 7 Aug: +1

Considering what the recent changes in reporting standards meant to the data of hospitalizations in Texas, I am intrigued what this will mean for today's figures for Arizona.
I expect the data of at least 23 July through 26 July 2020 will no longer fully reflect the state of the situation and the value of the data will continue to be impaired throughout the month in a way that any of the forecasts could accidentally be right or wrong.
Suggesting a resolution for the second bin ("Between 26 June 2020 and 09 July 2020"), considering the impact of enactment of "Crisis Standards of Care", I received a negative reply and the info, that the question will be resolved under the terms of the question, which to me means strictly from the data of AZ Health Department. I guess the new reporting standards will not change the jury's stance, even if it will be obvious that official data will no longer be consistent from today on. Forecasting a moving target is a different thing, especially when the target is out of bounds. Still, I consider the situation in Arizona dire enough to expect a resolution of this question before 06 August 2020.

According to this page here https://covidactnow.org/us/az/?s=748129  and their rather static model, the available Adult Intensive Care Unit bed capacity has already fallen below 5% on 05 July 2020 (to 4%) and has ever since 07 July 2020 been used to a capacity degree larger than 100%, as already others have noted:
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1078772
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1073960 I don't really know how they can produce two so much different figures from those of the AZ officials on one and the same topic; the only explanation I have is the "Crisis Standards of Care", which have obviously been enacted two days ahead of the 95% static threshold and four days ahead of the ICU's running at full capacity. https://eu.azcentral.com/story/news/local/arizona-health/2020/06/29/arizona-leaders-doctors-crisis-care-standards-coronavirus/3280852001/
https://eu.azcentral.com/story/opinion/op-ed/ej-montini/2020/06/30/crisis-care-standards-arizona-code-coronavirus-death-panels/3285410001/
I don't exactly know what it entails, but it seems very strict protocols for ICU treatment have been relaxed, and the standards to fulfill for a bed to be declared an ICU bed will have been lowered.
It seems at a realistic measurement, one has to acknowledge that the question will have already been answered "YES" in the second bin. Every dynamic that has raised the ICU capacity since 05 July 2020, has happened under "Crisis Standards of Care", which raises the issue: is an ICU bed under the rule of "Crisis Standards of Care" still comparable to an ICU bed as of the question #1654 at starting date 12 June 2020? https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1083613 The German TV news channel n-tv reported (once again) today on their ticker that ICU capacity of Florida and Arizona are filled, which I interpret as "used to 100%"; I wonder where they have this from, but at the moment no specific link is available.

Sharp drop off for the 20th. Will probably be a small surge the 21th as usual for Tuesday numbers, but the downward trend is clear now. Leaving a small, small possibility for a surge 24 Jul-6 Aug.  10 Jul-23 Jul: -2
24 Jul-6Aug: -4
Not before 7 Aug: +6
surge capacity ap[pears to have been deployed sufficiently

Giving up and admitting I have no understanding of how AZ worked the magic necessary to avoid what seemed to be such an obvious train wreck headed their way in mid-June. The suffering of both patients and medical staff described by the media just did not translate into the published data. Paying attention to this challenge exhausted me. I’m done.
The percentage of ICU’s in usage is slowing going down, therefore I am increasing the likelihood that available ICU’s will not fall below 5% before August 7.

Number of people in ICU beds because of Covid-19 peaked 13 July at 970 beds, 18 July it was down to 894. (There is a chance there is lag in the data reporting.) The total number of ICU beds usage seem to be stable and even slightly declining.[1] Still to early to set anything at 100% for me, but more and more indicators tells me the peak has been reached. 10-23 July: -7
24 July - 6 August: -4
Not before 7 August: +11 1. All numbers from Arizona's Covid-19 dashboard linked to in the question.

The phenomenon of procrastinating the collapse of intensive care in Arizona may be owed to a deterioration of standards in hospitals to gain more "flexibility".
In the first days of July, obviously "Crisis Standards of Care" have been implemented  https://www.azmirror.com/2020/07/03/as-covid-19-worsens-az-is-the-first-state-to-enact-crisis-care-standards/ which might mean that patients who require ICU treatment could also be shifted to Emergency Department standard beds, or even outright triage: they let severely ill people die to free beds quickly, which is supported by todays record daily death toll in Arizona.
They're still on thin ice, however, and all measures included, they gained about just 20 beds for the whole state. After this, it seems, there's no double bottom left, and the decline in new cases is owed rather to less testing over the weekend than to less occurrence or transmission  of the virus; positivity rate is still on record levels.

While Arizona has been at 91% they have gone down to 88% and have been yo-yo-ing between that and 90% since. The new case numbers have seemed to stabilized and I suspect it will be past August 7 before they are under 5% ICU capacity.

It is flat for 2 weeks which is a new trend time. Since our horizon is 3 weeks, seems like a good basis for a forecast.
Also, is is flat around 10% which seems like a humanly significant number. Maybe something is "holding it there" like it is a minimum capacity that must stay open

The data reported on the website does not come close to matching the reports coming from multiple news outlets, including interviews with medical staff in the state. It also doesn’t seem to track with data coming from similarly hard-hit states. There are likely areas of the state with unused capacity factored into the data to offset places like Phoenix and Tucson, which seem to be at capacity. Additional capacity is also being created by scaling up under suboptimal conditions (repurposing wings and overworking staff). Quote from linked article (https://www.thedailybeast.com/arizona-doctors-say-gov-doug-ducey-steered-state-into-covid-19-surge): One ICU physician in Tucson, who asked not to be named for fear of employer retaliation, said the official numbers actually underplayed the severity of the crisis. When hospitals reported that 90 percent of their ICU beds and half of their ventilators were in use, the physician said, those numbers included the extra beds and machines they’d brought in for the pandemic. If those percentages ever reached 100, there would be no feasible way for the hospital to scale up. “If you were going by our pre-COVID capacity, we would be actually operating at 120 percent of capacity,” the physician said, adding that the hospital where they work had run out of its own ventilator supply and was now using those supplied by FEMA.
Not sure where they're putting the sick folks, but not in Arizona ICU beds.

The governor is in hiding, being in AZ, the data does not reflect the current condition of the hospitals. I believe the data is reporting inaccurately. The morgue ordered refrigerated trucks because they ran out of capacity. The numbers are not reported consistently, but on Tue/Wed in which you will get a high number (70-90), and all other days will be lower (5-30)

More indications of a reached peak. To much uncertainty to put anything at 100%, but adjusting.  Between 10-23 July: -21
Between 24 July-6 August: -1
Not before 7 August: +22
Looks like they peaked and made it.  I am glad to have been wrong.

@SE_Meyer makes some very good points. One good bus accident could put them up to 95%. I am going to redistribute. The SE_Meyer dive into the data is also deeper than mine. I will, however, watch daily and if no movement upward will reconsider.

Been looking at this. 5% of cases hospitalized so for 3000 that is about 150. At one point they were discharging about 200 or more a day. It all depends on surge in cases. Hospitals also had a surge plan to add ICU beds. Probably not making it to 95%.
Hovering @90pc.  See previous forecast.  Upping probability to later dates

All of the stats I am looking at show Arizona has peaked. Test data is likely a week behind, but emergency room visits, ventilators, and ICU beds with CoVid all show them holding their own.  Recovery graph from different source indicates the same. https://www.covidexitstrategy.org/
Positivity rate has been growing significantly, updated to put more mass on this happening before Aug 7.
Daily new cases seems to have already peaked
88 % today and tracking downwards. Looks like its not happening due to a number of factors, denominator increasing, out of state help, inflow of medical professionals to staff ICU beds

Once they hit about 90% capacity they brought more beds online, bringing the % down. They have maybe 400-500 more reserve beds they can bring online, and they seem to want to keep a buffer of available beds. With the number of new patients starting to trend downward I really don't see this hitting 96% capacity.
Still holding steady at 90% and number of inpatients overall are starting to drop.

Arizona is currently reporting 90% usage, while another source (https://covidactnow.org/us/az/?s=665110) reports they're already overwhelmed. Combined with a dangerous heat index, I'm inclined to split the difference and say they'll be reporting capacity by the end of the week.
Looking a Covid-19 tracking data the number if cases dipped for a day and hospitalizations did not drastically go up.

The peak of hospitalization has not been reached reading from the chart. Given the peak has not been achieved and 70% of ICU bed being used currently, it may take additional 14-20 weeks to goes back down based on COVID hospitalization modeling data.
Updating: didn't happen yet. It's definitely trending downward though.

Never mind that ICU bed capacity runs about 75%  in the best of times.      All bypass patients,  all vent patients from any cause and septic shock from all causes are in there.  ICU beds are mostly full in 2028,  2019   and 2020 and will be in 2021.   YOu do not even give a cause!

While COVID ICU beds keep creeping up, only 922 beds out of 1511 ICU beds are COVID.  Their putting off of elective surgeries and other measures Seem to have stabilized the %.  New intubations are trending down. Additionally, while some hospitals have achieved 100%, other more rural hospitals have not.  The 5% may be a result of that.  I am keeping some chance because of the holidays, but suspect it will also primarily hit hospitals already full, not the ones with empty beds.

Taking a risk here, perhaps too much risk. Comments: 1) it appears that growth of cases has slowed in AZ (although I do worry that this surge was in the 25-45 age range and could lead to a 2nd surge in the >65 range); 2) the number of beds keeps increasing (e.g. they can turn off elective surgeries and make those recovery beds available for COVID patients) and 3) there is slack elsewhere in the system like LTACs and SNFs. On the other hand: this is a "maximum" question, so therefore vulnerable to 1-day data quirks. That's why I've made it 5% in the lower buckets rather than zero.

For the moment I will go down. Checking a graphic of the ICU bed occupancy during the peak of the pandemic in New York: https://projects.thecity.nyc/2020_03_covid-19-tracker/ It seems that they never reached the 95% rate. But it is unclear though: the graphic does not contain numbers and it only shows from April 1 onwards. Right now Arizona is still increasing their numbers of ICU beds: 1730 as of today. Thus for this question to be closed, we would need 1644 occupied beds. The question is the following: are they aiming for a fixed minimum percentage of free ICU beds or for a free minimum number of free ICU beds? I would say that it would be easier to aim for the second: the number of free beds have been moving from 150-200 during the last two weeks, despite the fact that the number of occupied ICU beds have reached yesterday a new record (1556). However it is also true that we have been stuck at the 10% level (of free ICU beds) for the last two weeks. Now my problem is that I cannot find a similar dashboard to the one of Arizona for NY and other states during their previous peaks. Having those, it would be much easier to use the outside view to determine the probability that they will never reach the 5% limit. Have you checked this by chance, @Anneinak @Dillyweed @bobrown @K-M-G @A356  ?

Temporarily going back to 100% due to: "The National Weather Service has issued an Excessive Heat Warning for 13 counties.
Coconino, Gila, Graham, Greenlee, Maricopa, Pima, and Pinal from 7/10 - 7/13 and Cochise, La Paz, Mohave, Santa Cruz, Yavapai, and Yuma from 7/11-7/13.
High temperatures ranging from 105° F to 120° F are expected from 10 AM – 8 PM.
Learn more about how to stay safe in extreme heat and stay informed about future heat alerts." As the risk of heat stroke is immense at temperatures of > 37°C already, more non-COVID-19 patients will come to hospitals, and may finally require ED or even ICU treatment. Even though this just means a short peak for three to four days, it may be enough to drive the available bed capacity down the cliff in the short term.

I'm not sure the crowd is being hugely rational having the majority of its credence in the 'soonest' bin after doing the same for the previous one and it not happening.  Even if one cannot explain why the occupancy is not rising as one expects (?aggressive triaging, ?committing to keep some surge capacity earmarked for trauma cases, ?something else), occupancy has been hovering around 90% for a week.  This seems to suggest shifting credence in later bins (as well as the immediately subsequent one) as time goes on. (And hey, my initial forecast was very off base, but I'm probably recovering better than a forecaster who was confident it was going to hit 95% before 10 July, now confident it will hit it before 23 July, and may become confident it will hit it before 7 Aug).
My goodness, this question is a real bumpy ride!
Changing because of the high number of positive cases could result soon in a surge of hospitalizations. Will go down early next week if I see a big lowering.

Tiny pieces of hope ... but the next few days will see if the holiday weekend changed things. Hospitalizations will see an increase again by Wednesday if surge happens. https://www.azcentral.com/story/news/local/arizona-health/2020/07/10/arizona-covid-19-update-july-10-new-cases-and-hospital-metrics-remain-high/5409783002/
I'll join @Cehra in the basement. This is not normal linear problem. The ceiling keeps moving the rules and the end zone keep changing. Critical to always keep some beds open.

Availability hovering at 10pc.  Hospitalisation have dropped off dramatically in the last 2 weeks, so it’s more likely beds will now free up than be occupied.  Changed forecasts for before 10 Jul to zero.  But left forecast for other as was.  it looks likely now that the 5pc threshold will not be reached.
Still at 89% as of July 10th. Seems stable at about 90 %

Not really sure why I overreacted yesterday. Things have just been growing very slowly in terms of the ICU with a lot of the fluctuation in percentages being in the denominator. I’m going to rebaseline myself. My original prior was that if this didn’t happen immediately, it would hold until August. That was because I thought bed numbers would grow, non-Covid patients would get moved out, and social distancing would kick in. I was wrong about bed numbers growing and social distancing, but patients have clearly gotten moved out. And that’s been enough to make the rise rather gradual. Additionally treatments have gotten better since spring.  I’m going much higher on it never reaching 95, with a split on it coming still reaching before August.

"As of July 2, 3013 (39%) of Arizona’s 7673 general ward beds were occupied by patients with suspected or confirmed Covid-19 infection, a 19% increase from last week. An additional 1135 (15%) beds remain available which is up from last week’s 1111 beds. Similarly, 741 (44%) of Arizona’s 1676 ICU beds were occupied for Covid-19 care, a 15% increase from last week. An additional 156 (9%) beds remain available which is lower than the 222 beds available last week. July 4th marked the first time that there more Covid-19 occupied ICU beds (54%) than non-Covid occupied beds. see Figure 5: COVID-19 Disease Outbreak Forecast Simplistic projections of non-surge general ward and ICU capacity suggest Arizona could reach ward capacity by mid-August (Figure 5). This projection is about two weeks later than estimated last week. Essentially, non-Covid admissions are falling somewhat faster than Covid-19 admissions are increasing as total ward capacity is relatively constant. While the safety margin in ward beds is being better preserved, ICU capacity is now under greater strain. If current trends persist, excess ICU capacity could be exhausted by late July."
https://publichealth.arizona.edu/news/2020/covid-19-forecast-model The staffing of beds is said to be the first thing to fall short.

It seems most cases with severe illness in AZ so far will have been treated in the Emergency Department (ED) instead of the ICU, and this number recently spiked very sharply by almost 50% over two days (1,289 on 30 June 2020 vs 1,847 on 02 July 2020). Some of these cases seem to have been put to the ICU afterwards, as the number of "ICU Beds for COVID-19" have inclined more sharply after 02 July 2020 than before (723 on 01 July 2020; 741 on 02 July 2020; 796 on 03 July 2020; 821 on 04 July 2020). This is maybe a replication of the observation from Texas medical system, where patients come to see a doctor first very (almost too) late, when symptoms and lack of oxigen have become harmful and ICU treatment is mandatory. As a consequence, the relation of ICU Beds (COVID-19)/ED patients (COVID-19) seems to increase over time, which suggests increasingly scarce ICU beds.
As the number of "Intubations Performed for Respiratory Distress" have been about 60 per day on average between 20 June 2020 and 02 July 2020, I'd say on 03/04 July 2020 alone there have been more than 90 additional (above average) intubations, which will block an ICU bed in the short term, as the recovery from COVID-19 will take at least two weeks, once an intubation has become necessary. If this trend in intubations continues, it will be ever harder to discharge patients from ICU beds soon.
Even when the number of "COVID-19 Patients Discharged from the hospital" is rising (which also just reflects the increase in "Inpatient  COVID-19 patients"), my guess is the discharge which has peaked on 04 July 2020 may not be enough to keep patients from being stuck to 95% (or rather 96%) of ICU beds very soon. And even if 02 July 2020 has been a specifically bad day with about 4,4k new confirmed cases, 05 July 2020 with about 3,5k new cases has not been much better, and positivity rate seems to be quite constant right now.

This is a forecast based on an SIR model run in R. Traditional epidemiological models haven't performed well in the context of this crisis, but my understanding is that this is largely due to their failure to take into account social dynamics. I've attempted to "price in" these dynamics by running my SIR model with a Monte Carlo simulation (10000 runs) using the following parameters: Recovered (R) = 80000
Infected (I) ~ Normal(12000,2000)
Population (N) = 7,300,000
Susceptible = N - I - R
R0 ~ PERT(0.8, 1.5, 2.5)
D ~ exp(1/18)
Hospitalizations = 2.5% of cases In the SIR model, R0 is the product of D and beta, which is the average number of contacts per person per day times the probability of infecting another person during a contact. I don't have any idea what beta is, so I've "backed it out" here by using a range of estimates for R0 based on a subjective reading of recent history.

I find this a very difficult forecast to compose, although I think the crowd errs a bit optimistic (naturally, I hope to be mistaken): [Also, the dashboard went down whilst I was writing this. I think it's fairly unlikely this was thanks to traffic from us, but Arizonans have greater need of this data than we do...] ANTICIPATED CRITICAL CASE LOAD: In other contexts, 5-8% of cases become critically ill.[1] These figures come from earlier outbreaks (e.g. Wuhan), and probably overestimate given under-ascertainment of mild/asymptomatic infections (cf. why raw case fatality ratios typically overestimate the infection fatality ratio for COVID-19. A dumb correction for this would be ~3%, highly sensitive to how avidly AZ tests (which I only have vague steers on - more later). 3% of ~1600 cases (the daily figure on June 12) gives 48 new expected critical cases, or 5% of ICU capacity. You would not need many of these days (~4) to exhaust present ICU capacity on this assumption (especially given how epi curves and reporting lags work, meaning one probably shouldn't expect this rising trend to reverse immediately) TIME LAGS TO PRESENTATION Hospitalizations for COVID-19 in AZ in the last few days were not huge (IIRC the graph before the dashboard went down, it was on a downward trend). I fear this is falsely reassuring due to expected lag times. Incubation periods average 5-6 days, and time from symptom onset to critical illness ~~9 days. The two upshots are 1) if there is indeed a surge in infections, you would not expect this to translate into critical cases immediately (thus the regrettable expectation the benign trends in hospitalizations etc. will reverse); 2) If most testing is screening on asymptomatic individuals (cf. the drive-thrus), this expected burden of critical cases may arise later - either pushing probability in the second time period versus the first, and giving time for AZ to respond by expanding ICU capacity (more later). ALAS PROBABLY NOT AN ARTEFACT OF TESTING MORE AZ has ramped up testing, including the use of serology tests (which can potentially pick up those who were infected and have recovered). One hope would be therefore that the apparent surge in positive tests is owed to these things rather than increasing incidence of infection.  Unfortunately, it does not seem a lot of the apparent surge can be attributed to this: 1) serology tests are the minority, so the numbers cannot be heavily inflated by recovered infections (which is in any case upper-bounded by some time-lagged prevalence); 2) % positives for PCR are rising - you would expect this proportion to fall if the increased cases were owed to increased testing rather than increased incidence. RESPONSE EFFICACY Media reports indicate AZ state gov concern and attempt to mitigate (e.g. hospitals activating emergency plans). Regrettably I am pessimistic on how effective this can prove, although more uncertainty attaches to how this is reported. The responses I see are these: a) preserving present capacity (e.g. cancelling elective operations); b) triage; c) expanding critical care capacity; d) reducing incidence a: One can 'free up' ICU beds by eliminating elective demand. This only gets you so far - there are many reasons besides COVID-19 for non-elective ICU admissions. My impression 'back in the day' was also these tended to be shorter stay (and so this may have already happened leaving limited further room to manoeuvre). b: Triaging ICU could effectively increase available capacity, by declining to escalate treatment for patients least likely to benefit. I think this is a minor factor: firstly, as if ICUs were heavily overdemanded, one would not leave 5% of available beds idle; secondly, my impression is the clinical ethos in the US is particularly loathe to limit care for a patient for reasons 'outside' their clinical condition, so I doubt there will be a lot of pre-emptive triage to preserve capacity for an anticipated influx of critically ill. c: Hospital emergency responses typically include means of expanding critical care resources, through a mix of reassigning staff, repurposing clinical areas, and so on. Thus the denominator of ICU beds available could increase. Yet i) these tend not to be hugely impressive - maybe a small multiple, and typically needing weeks to spin up; ii) it's not clear whether this 'improvised capacity' (e.g. if you open a 'CPAP/HFNO' ward for severely ill cases) would be counted as ICU beds. In any case, if you get to this stage ICU is typically full (cf. Lombardy, etc.)  MISC Listing qualitative considerations either way then reading tea-leaves to aggregate them is typically not a great forecasting technique. I'd like to evaluate other places more carefully to get a clearer sense on how to benchmark these considerations. I expect there will be a lot more resolution in the next few days with data on hospitalizations etc. I'd expect my guesses in these buckets to change by 20+%. I am surprised at the crowd putting a lot of mass in buckets 1m+ away. The likely outcomes seem more bimodal to me.

At the current rate of ~60 hospitalizations a day, assuming that rate doesn’t increase, and assuming on average 25% of those hospitalizations (15 per day) require an ICU bed (which is approximately the rate of intubations required in NY relative to hospitalizations at the peak of the first wave of the pandemic), it implies 225 beds would be taken in 15 days (days remaining till the first cutoff date in the question). If we also assume no existing beds free up nor additional capacity is added, that means 5% of the total 1,665 beds is ~83 beds. Those 83 beds removed from the remaining 337 beds as of June 11th implies 254 beds would need to be used to get to the 5% level. That shows us there are still 29 additional beds available or two more days of available capacity above the 5% level. All this said, intubations aren’t the same thing as ICU bed usage to my knowledge. I’d assume ICU bed usage is slightly higher than intubations. And, the current rate of hospitalizations in Arizona appears to be increasing at this time. Additionally, it often takes quite some time for people to come out of ICU once they’re admitted, so the rate of already utilized beds becoming available is likely to decrease. So, we could easily see those additional 29 beds used within that time frame. The only caveat I’d like to add is that excess capacity being added is a game changer. Makeshift hospitals can be made or regular rooms can be converted into ICU rooms. And, since the existing total beds has increased over time on the graph discussed, it’s clear that is taken into consideration. It’s cutting it extremely tight. But, Arizona sees the current need and believes it is going to get worse. Therefore, they’re likely to increase the number of ICU beds during this time period, especially since they told hospitals to activate emergency plans on June 8th. I believe it’ll be just prior to or just after the initial cut off date, but will go with prior to based on the above as I believe rates will increase faster than the rate of increased ICU beds.
